oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Military Pass for Mr. Morey and Family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small document serving as a military pass allowing the bearers, Ira Morey and his family, to travel through the Union lines for ten days. On the back of the pass, which was issued by General Negley, is the oath of allegiance taken by Ira Morey.

Ira Morey served as a Presbyterian minister in several states before arriving in Tennessee in 1849. In 1856, he accepted a position with the Abbe Institute, a school for young ladies in Lebanon, Tenn. In 1858, Rev. Morey moved his family to Franklin, Tennessee. In 1865, Hannah Herrick Morey, Ira's wife, made a futile attempt to obtain the release of their son, James Marsh Morey, from the Union prison on Hart's Island, New York.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Civil War in the West; Civil War society; United States - History - 1783-1865; United States - History - 1849-1877; United States History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Nashville (Tenn.)
